designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) strategic framework for 2012–20221 identifies 
climate change as a priority for the GMS economic corridor development agenda. Individual 
developing member countries (DMCs) in the GMS have initiated efforts to integrate climate 
change  adaptation  into  national  development  strategies  and  policies,  but  this  has  not  yet 
translated into agendas for cities. Under Strategy 2020, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
identifies environmentally sustainable growth, including climate change, as a key development 
concern and a core area for ADB operations.2 Promoting climate-resilient development and 
encouraging climate-friendly urban development are two key priorities for action under ADB’s 
climate  change  agenda.3  ADB's  regional  departments  have  formulated  climate  change 
implementation plans to effectively mainstream climate change concerns in country partnership 
strategies. ADB’s urban operational plan also places high importance on adaptation to climate 
change, and infrastructure investments and enhancements are seen as part of the “competitive 
cities” agenda, to ensure a sustainable urban future. 
 
2.  The regional capacity development technical assistance (TA), GMS: Climate Resilience in 
Cities, was conceptualized in response to the request for assistance with urban climate change 
adaptation, articulated in workshops for preparing the GMS corridor towns development projects 
in Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), and Viet Nam during 2011–
2012.4 The project cities identified the need to facilitate policy dialogue and knowledge exchange 
on climate resilience.5  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Urban areas in the GMS are highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. The 
increasing frequency and severity of extreme climate events (such as floods, droughts, and 
tropical storms), rising sea level, and threats to infrastructure and population centers pose 
serious challenges to sustainable development across the GMS. The extensive coastline and 
seasonal variability associated with tropical monsoons makes the GMS countries especially 
vulnerable to climate change, impacting not only agriculture, but also manufacturing and service 
sectors. The poor are particularly at risk as they tend to live in environmentally fragile locations, 
depend for their livelihood on sectors that are especially prone to climate change, and do not 
have adequate savings to recover from disasters. Further, their tenuous access to adaptation 
technologies and institutional support make them particularly vulnerable. 
 
4.  Rapid urbanization is taking place in Southeast Asia, with cities in the region expanding 
five times faster than those in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation 
and Development (OECD). Urban growth in the GMS in the 50-100 years is expected to be 
primarily in small and medium-sized cities and peri-urban areas along existing and new growth 
corridors.  Rapid  urbanization  is  expected  to  increase  built-up  areas  substantially.  As  local

adaptation. 
 
5.   To cope with climate change, GMS countries have initiated national climate change 
mitigation and adaptation policies. However, progress in implementing subnational policies to 
address adaptation, especially in urban areas, has been limited.  Many cities are unable to plan 
and implement climate change adaptation measures primarily because of (i) lack of policy-
relevant  information,  (ii)  technical  barriers,  (iii)  financial  limitations,  and  (iv)  institutional 
constraints. Further, national climate change policies have not yet been translated into local 
climate adaptation policies for urban areas. For example, in Cambodia and the Lao PDR, 
climate change dialogue focusing on urban areas has only been seriously initiated in towns 
such as Sihanoukville in Cambodia and Luang Prabang in the Lao PDR. However, Viet Nam is 
an exception as the Viet Nam Urban Forum recently initiated the Urban Strategy for Climate 
Change Adaptation.7 However policies developed for large cities may not always be appropriate 
for small and medium-sized towns. 
 
6.  The  TA  will  address  these  barriers  through  policy  dialogue  and  the  preparation  of 
appropriate guidebooks, with a focus on selected towns such as Battambang in Cambodia, 
Kaysone Phomvihane in the Lao PDR, and Dong Ha in Viet Nam. These towns were selected 
because of their unique characteristics of riverine and coastal flood vulnerability representing a 
large flood-prone watershed area (Battambang, Tonle Sap Basin), the seasonally changing and 
flood-prone Mekong River (Kaysone Phomvihane), and proximity to the typhoon-prone coastline 
to be affected by sea level rise (Dong Ha).8 All three towns have diverse geographies, needs, 
and capacity; but each is highly vulnerable to natural disasters and the impacts of climate 
change. 
 
7.  The TA will create a platform for exchange of adaptation relevant information among 
small and medium-sized towns. Policy dialogue on adaptation will help formulate structural and 
nonstructural measures, such as building construction regulations and development of criteria 
and incentives for the certification of green buildings in line with the identified issues. Likewise, 
preparation of guidebooks on locally relevant adaptation approaches and technologies will be 
useful to disseminate appropriate and low-cost solutions to other  small and  medium-sized 
towns.  
 
8.  The  TA  will  build  on  experiences  with  other  ADB-supported  projects  and  promote 
synergies with relevant projects in the GMS.  For example, recent ADB assistance to the GMS 
has focused on biodiversity management,9 spatial technologies for climate modeling as a tool to 
aid decision making for identifying hazard areas and formulating zoning laws,10 and assessing 
climate change vulnerability in the energy and transport sectors in Viet Nam.11 In terms of 
gender-responsive tools for climate change adaptation, ADB is working on mitigation measures

9.  The TA will collaborate extensively with the GMS corridor towns development projects in 
Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam in which investments will cover environmental urban 
infrastructure  (drainage  and  flood  control,  solid  waste  management,  wastewater  treatment, 
urban roads and drainage, and river embankments) in 10 towns along the southern and east–
west economic corridors.14 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact of the TA is more socially inclusive and climate-resilient urban 
infrastructure developed in GMS cities. The outcome will be enhanced understanding of climate 
change impacts and adaptation options by key stakeholders in GMS cities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will assist small and medium-sized GMS towns in sharing knowledge and 
conducting policy dialogue on climate change adaptation. Participating towns will learn 
about  appropriate  and  available  tools  and  processes  necessary  to  adapt  to  climate 
change. The policy dialogue and cross-learning will be supported by a handbook on 
good practices from the region and internationally. The TA will strengthen local policy 
frameworks, and help cities identify suitable solutions and approaches, and the means to 
implement them. Under the ensuing loans for the three GMS countries, various climate change 
adaptation infrastructure investments are being proposed; their implementation will commence in 
2013. As a supplementary activity to the loan investment projects, the TA will help ensure that 
the climate-proofing measures for different infrastructure investments are adhered to in all the 
subprojects of the 10 corridor towns during preparation of the detailed engineering design, 
implementation of construction activities, and operation and maintenance. 
 
12.  Output  1:  Knowledge-sharing  workshops  and  policy  dialogue.  Knowledge-
sharing  and  dialogue  events  (seminars,  workshops,  study  tours,  and  cross-learning 
among  peers)15  will  focus  on  citywide  responses.  The  dialogue  will  involve  local 
stakeholders  (government  and  private),  and  address  possible  partnerships  between  these 
stakeholders. The dialogue is intended to translate to better policies and practice, and to 
contribute to the handbook for resilient cities (output 2). The policy dialogue will take into 
account innovations of climate adaptation in the GMS and beyond, and test their applicability in 
small and medium-sized towns. The dialogue participants will most likely be members of the 
respective project implementation units of the project towns, and representatives from local 
nongovernment organizations and women’s unions. Special efforts will be made to involve

vulnerable communities including senior citizens, children, and youth.  The dialogue process 
will raise awareness and generate support for the resilience planning process. It is expected to 
result  in  the  development  of  locally  appropriate  policies and  practices  for  climate-resilient 
infrastructure development (flood control and drainage, adaptation of water and sanitation 
facilities, and solid waste management), local building codes and zoning laws, as well social 
and gender aspects of resilience. The dialogues will also (i) identify and document coping 
mechanisms, especially those that are indigenous in nature in the selected corridor towns; and 
(ii) identify policy mechanisms that will institutionalize these coping mechanisms. 
 
13.   Output 2: Development of a handbook for climate-resilient cities in the Greater 
Mekong Subregion. The handbook (in English, Khmer, Lao, and Vietnamese languages) will 
focus on climate adaptation responses for urban infrastructure, such as flood control and 
drainage, water and sanitation, wastewater treatment, and solid waste management. It will also 
provide a user-friendly, step-by-step approach to develop an action plan for short-, medium-, 
and  long-term  structural  and  nonstructural  measures  designed  to  increase  urban  climate 
resilience and focus on tools appropriate for the local situation of GMS cities.16 Towns will be 
encouraged  to  customize  the  handbook  based  on  their  prior  planning  and  capacity.  The 
handbook may include geographic information system maps that illustrate current and future 
vulnerabilities of neighborhoods and communities. The handbook will include an inventory of 
current and future plans for town development in order to assess gaps and needs as a basis for 
framing resilience measures. The options for financing resilience measures and considerations 
for scaling up various resilience measures and practices will also be documented. In the long 
run, the handbook is expected to be a key vehicle for mainstreaming adaptation and disaster 
risk reduction into urban planning. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Nordic Development Fund, and administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented from 1 October 2012 to 31 March 2014. ADB will be the 
executing agency with the Urban Development and Water Division, Southeast Asia Department 
as the focal point. ADB will establish a TA team comprising staff from the Urban Development 
and Water Division, which will monitor TA activities, provide guidance, and give input and 
feedback on a regular basis. The team will work closely with other Southeast Asia Department 
climate change-related projects, and the GMS Environmental Operations Centre to ensure that 
the  TA  complements  their  efforts.  The  team  will  liaise  with  partner  organizations  actively 
involved in similar activities. The TA implementing agencies are as follows:  
 
(i)  Cambodia: Ministry of Public Works and Transport. The work of the implementing 
agency will be supported by a steering committee, proposed to consist of the 
Ministry of Environment; and the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning 
and Construction. 
(ii)  Lao PDR: Ministry of Public Works and Transport. The work of the implementing 
agency will be supported by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment.

Rockefeller Foundation, and Climate Cities Initiative, supported by the Clinton Foundation.

5 
(iii)  Viet Nam: Provincial People’s Committee of Quang Tri Province. The work of the 
implementing agency will be supported by the Ministry of Construction and the 
Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment.17 
 
16.  The  TA  will  require  the  services  of  a  consulting  firm,  with  a  team  of  experts  with 
experience and a track record in climate adaptation projects, urban development, and project 
management. ADB will recruit the firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method in 
compliance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The quality- and cost-based selection method will have a technical and financial ratio of 
80:20.  ADB  will  also  recruit  a  regional  development  specialist  using  individual  consultant 
selection.  The  specialist,  to  be  based  at  ADB  headquarters,  will  provide  technical  and 
administrative support for the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The experiences and lessons from this TA will be disseminated through handbooks to 
governments, the private sector, and agencies working on developing and financing innovative, 
environmental, and pro-poor urban infrastructure for climate resilient cities. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 to be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  the  Nordic  Development  Fund  for  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion:  Climate 
Resilience in Cities, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of a consulting firm with a team of 
experts with experience and a track record in climate technology policy formulation, urban 
development, and project management. The consulting firm will be selected through the quality- 
and  cost-based  selection  method.  An  individual  national  consultant  will  be  recruited  (by 
individual  consultant  selection)  to  provide  administrative  and  technical  support  during  TA 
implementation.  Detailed  terms  of  reference,  number  of  consultancy  inputs,  and  selection 
methods will be defined during the processing of the capacity development TA grant. The 
consultant selection process will be executed in compliance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
 
A.  Specialists and Description of Tasks 
 
1.  Climate Change Specialist and Team Leader 
 
2.  Basic qualifications. The specialist should have (i) a postgraduate degree (master’s 
or doctorate) related to climate change; (ii) at least 8 years of professional experience in climate 
change adaptation of which 3 years are in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS); and (iii) at 
least 5 years experience in managing development projects, preferably in a multi-geographic 
setup. 
 
3.  For output 1: policy dialogue (approximately 2 person-months), the specialist will  
 
(i)  provide overall management and supervision of activities to ensure the delivery 
of the TA output, 
(ii)  prepare the policy dialogue agenda, 
(iii)  prepare and conduct policy dialogues, 
(iv)  prepare workshop and/or seminar materials 
(v)  prepare and conduct workshops and/or seminars, 
(vi)  prepare training materials, 
(vii)  prepare and conduct training events, and 
(viii)  prepare a synthesis report of agreements. 
 
4.  For output 2: development of a handbook for resilient cities in the GMS (approximately  
6 person-months), the specialist will  
 
(i)  provide overall management and supervision of activities to ensure delivery of 
the TA output; 
(ii)  review  available  sector  studies  and  other  climate  change  handbooks  and 
guidelines;  
(iii)  conduct needed field surveys and observations; 
(iv)  prepare the Handbook for Resilient Cities in the GMS; 
(v)  conduct expert peer review of the draft handbook; 
(vi)  finalize the handbook; 
(vii)  review outputs of national consultants and recommend follow-up actions; 
(viii)  oversee the production of the handbook in the English language; and 
(ix)  oversee  the  translation  and  production  of  the  handbook  in  three  national 
languages (Khmer, Lao, and Vietnamese).

(ii)  provide advice to implementing agencies on climate adaptation infrastructure; 
(iii)  provide  advice  to  implementing  agencies  on  project  implementation,  working 
closely with project officers, analysts, and consulting services staff, of the Urban 
Development and Water Division, Southeast Asia Department; 
(iv)  assist ADB staff in administering the TA; 
(v)  review regular reports on TA status for achieving intended outputs and goals; 
(vi)  help ADB staff track TA outputs against the ADB results framework; 
(vii)  monitor contract awards and disbursement performance on contract awards and 
disbursements, and consult with parties concerned on reasons for deviation and 
proposed courses of action to meet targets; 
(viii)  provide background analysis of problems encountered in project implementation;  
(ix)  help  ADB  staff  monitor  submission  of  project  safeguard  documents,  and 
compliance with safeguards and ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2011); 
and 
(x)  coordinate economic and sector work: (a) contribute information and analyses for 
economic and sector work and ADB internal working groups; (b) contribute to 
analytical and advisory work, including policy and institutional analysis; liaise with 
government agencies and development partners to ensure ADB staff are kept 
informed of emergent issues; and (c) support ADB coordination with government 
and development and project partners to assist development of policy reforms. 
 
B.  Deliverables 
 
11.  The following are the deliverables of the consultants under the TA project: 
 
(i)  a  handbook  on  resilient  cities  in  the  GMS  in  English,  Khmer,  Lao,  and 
Vietnamese; and 
(ii)  a  synthesized  report  on  the  agreements  of  the  regional  and  national  policy 
dialogue.
